title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: femtograd R package implementing automatic differentiation (AD) via backpropagation using computational graphs. ’s inspired Karpathy’s micrograd implemented R using R6 classes. focus pedagogy modern statistics rather large-scale ML. Key capabilities: - First-order gradients via reverse-mode AD (backpropagation) - Second-order derivatives (Hessians) via forward--reverse AD - Built-log-likelihood functions exponential family distributions - MLE optimization Newton-Raphson gradient ascent - Statistical inference utilities (standard errors, confidence intervals)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses directed acyclic graph (DAG) represent mathematical expressions: data: numeric value grad: Gradient computed backpropagation backward_fn: Function defining local gradient computation prev: List parent nodes Operations: S3 methods differentiable operations (+, -, *, /, ^, log, exp, sqrt, sin, cos, lgamma, digamma, sigmoid, etc.)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Second derivatives computed via forward--reverse mode: dual: Class forward-mode AD. Stores (primal, tangent) pairs. Creating dual numbers value-object primals tangents Running forward pass (builds primal tangent graphs) tangent expression represents df/dθᵢ Running backward tangent gives d²f/dθⱼdθᵢ

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Log-likelihoods: loglik_normal, loglik_exponential, loglik_poisson, loglik_binomial, loglik_gamma, loglik_beta Optimization: gradient_ascent, gradient_descent, newton_raphson, find_mle Inference: fisher_information, std_errors, vcov_matrix, confint_mle, wald_test

title: CLAUDE.md
code: devtools::document()  # Generate roxygen2 docs devtools::build() devtools::install()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Test files: - test-ops.R: Arithmetic, transcendentals, activation functions - test-numerical-gradients.R: Gradient validation via finite differences - test-math-ops.R: lgamma, digamma, sin, cos, etc. - test-dual.R: Forward-mode AD dual number operations - test-hessian.R: Hessian computation - test-distributions.R: Log-likelihood functions - test-optimize.R: Optimization MLE routines

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Pedagogy performance: Code written clarity, speed Statistics focus: Designed MLE, Hessians, inference rather deep learning Graph Construction: Operations automatically build computational graphs Lazy Gradient Computation: Gradients computed backward() call Gradient Accumulation: Parent node gradients accumulate multiple children

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R dispatches S3 methods based first argument. means: Always put value object first binary operations.
code: x <- val(5) x * 2     # Works: dispatches to *.value 2 * x     # FAILS: dispatches to *.default (numeric)

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # WRONG: Creates new value, breaks graph rate <- rate + lr * grad(rate)  # CORRECT: Update data in place data(rate) <- data(rate) + lr * grad(rate)

title: CLAUDE.md
code: loss_fn <- function(p) {   mu <- p[[1]]   sigma <- p[[2]]   loglik_normal(mu, sigma, data) } params <- list(val(0), val(1)) H <- hessian(loss_fn, params) se <- std_errors(H, is_loglik = TRUE)

title: CLAUDE.md
code: result <- find_mle(loglik_fn, initial_params) result$estimate  # MLE values result$se        # Standard errors result$vcov      # Variance-covariance matrix

title: Authors and Citation
text: Alexander Towell. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Towell (2025). femtograd: Like Micrograd, Worse. R package version 0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {femtograd: Like Micrograd, But Worse},   author = {Alexander Towell},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.9000}, }

title: Like Micrograd, But Worse
text: Exponential distribution Automatic differentiation (AD) ’s quick demonstration use femtograd R package. Load like :
code: library(femtograd) #>  #> Attaching package: 'femtograd' #> The following object is masked from 'package:utils': #>  #>     data

title: Like Micrograd, But Worse
text: Let’s create simple loglikelihood function exponential distribution paramterized λ\lambda (failure rate). fTi(ti|λ)=λexp(−λti).   f_{T_i}(t_i | \lambda) = \lambda \exp(-\lambda t_i). , loglikelihood function just ℓ(λ)=nlogλ−λ∑=1nti.   \ell(\lambda) = n \log \lambda - \lambda \sum_{=1}^n t_i. Let’s generate n=30n=30 observations. see MLE θ̂\hat\theta 6.2455349.

title: Like Micrograd, But Worse
text: Finding value (argmax) maximizes log-likelihood function trivial solve case, closed-form solution. However, demonstrate use femtograd, construct loglike_exp function generator returns object can automatically differentiated (AD) using backpropogation, efficient way applying chain-rule expressions (like exp{yax2}\exp\{y x^2\} using computational graph represents expression. kind computational graphs nice property differentiable expression can model software, partial derivative respect node graph can efficiently accurately computed without resorting numerical finite difference methods slow, potentially difficult compose symbolic methods. many libraries . library based excellent work Karpathy developed Python library known micrograd, developed explicit purpose teaching basic concept AD backpropagation minimizing loss functions neural networks. Let’s solve MLE iteratively demonstration use femtograd. First, construct log-likelihood generator: Initially, guess λ̂\hat\lambda 11, terrible estimate. Gradient clipping technique prevent taking large step gradients become large (remember gradients local feature, generally use take big step) optimization, can cause instability overshooting optimal value. limiting step size, gradient clipping helps ensure optimization takes smaller, stable steps. R code: find MLE using simple iteration (200 loops). gradient ascent method converge MLE? ’s worth pointing update loglik gradient ascent loop, since needed gradient (score) case. , however, needed know log-likelihood reason, using line search method avoid overshooting, need update loglik <- loglike_exp(rate, data) time loop.
code: loglike_exp <- function(rate, data) {   return(log(rate)*length(data) - rate * sum(data)) } rate <- val(1) # Takes a gradient `g` and an optional `max_norm` parameter, which defaults # to 1. It calculates the gradient's L2 norm (Euclidean norm) and scales the # gradient down if its norm exceeds the specified max_norm. This is used during # the gradient ascent loop to help ensure stable optimization. grad_clip <- function(g, max_norm = 1) {   norm <- sqrt(sum(g * g))   if (norm > max_norm) {     g <- (max_norm / norm) * g   }   g } loglik <- loglike_exp(rate, data) lr <- 0.2 # learning rate for (i in 1:200) {   zero_grad(loglik)   backward(loglik)    data(rate) <- data(rate) + lr * grad_clip(grad(rate))   if (i %% 50 == 0)     cat("iteration", i, ", rate =", data(rate), ", drate/dl =", grad(rate), "\n") } #> iteration 50 , rate = 6.238781 , drate/dl = 0.006148105  #> iteration 100 , rate = 6.245533 , drate/dl = 1.447689e-06  #> iteration 150 , rate = 6.245535 , drate/dl = 3.418377e-10  #> iteration 200 , rate = 6.245535 , drate/dl = 8.082424e-14 (converged <- (abs(mle.rate - data(rate)) < 1e-3)) #> [1] TRUE

what: dual R6 class for forward-mode automatic differentiation — dual
title: dual R6 class for forward-mode automatic differentiation — dual
text: dual R6 class forward-mode automatic differentiation dual R6 class forward-mode automatic differentiation

title: dual R6 class for forward-mode automatic differentiation — dual
text: Represents dual number (primal, tangent) computing directional derivatives via forward-mode AD. combined reverse-mode (value), enables Hessian computation via forward--reverse. Forward-mode AD propagates derivatives alongside values forward pass. function f(x), setting tangent(x) = 1 gives f'(x) tangent output. Hessian computation (forward--reverse): primal value object (reverse-mode gradient) tangent also value object (tracks d/dx gradient) backward() primal, tangent grad gives Hessian entries

text: primal function value (can numeric value object) tangent directional derivative (can numeric value object)

title: Fisher scoring optimizer — fisher_scoring
text: Similar Newton-Raphson uses expected Fisher information (negative expected Hessian) instead observed Hessian. stable problems.

title: Fisher scoring optimizer — fisher_scoring
Fisher scoring optimizer — fisher_scoring
text: loglik_fn Log-likelihood function params List value objects (initial parameter values) max_iter Maximum iterations, default 100 tol Convergence tolerance, default 1e-8 verbose Print progress every N iterations (0 silent)

title: Fisher scoring optimizer — fisher_scoring
text: structure newton_raphson

title: Fisher scoring optimizer — fisher_scoring
text: regular exponential families, Fisher scoring equivalent Newton-Raphson since observed = expected information. Fisher scoring: θ_n+1 = θ_n + (θ_n)⁻¹ S(θ_n) = -EH (Fisher information) S = gradient (score). implementation uses observed Hessian approximation expected Hessian, making identical Newton-Raphson. true Fisher scoring implementation, one need compute EH analytically via Monte Carlo.

what: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: Computes Hessian matrix (matrix second partial derivatives) scalar function respect vector parameters. Uses forward-mode AD top reverse-mode AD efficient, accurate computation.

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: loss_fn function takes list parameters returns scalar loss/objective. function must use femtograd operations. params list value objects (parameters) value_creator Function create value objects (default: val). allows customization different value types.

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: numeric matrix dimension (n x n) n = length(params), containing Hessian d²f/dθᵢdθⱼ

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: Hessian computed using forward--reverse mode AD: parameter , create dual numbers : Primal = value object holding parameter value Tangent = value object (1 param , 0 others) Run loss function dual-value inputs tangent loss df/dθᵢ (value expression) Call backward() tangent loss tangent parameter's gradient gives d²f/dθⱼdθᵢ "forward--reverse" pattern: forward-mode (dual numbers) computes df/dθᵢ symbolically, reverse-mode differentiates get d²f/dθⱼdθᵢ.

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Hessian of f(x,y) = x^2 + x*y + y^2 loss_fn <- function(p) {   x <- p[[1]]   y <- p[[2]]   x^2 + x*y + y^2 } params <- list(val(1), val(2)) H <- hessian(loss_fn, params) # H should be [[2, 1], [1, 2]] } # }

title: Beta distribution log-likelihood — loglik_beta
text: Computes log-likelihood ..d. beta observations. L(α,β|x) = n*[log(Γ(α+β)) - log(Γ(α)) - log(Γ(β))] +            (α-1)*Σlog(xᵢ) + (β-1)*Σlog(1-xᵢ)

title: Beta distribution log-likelihood — loglik_beta

title: Binomial distribution log-likelihood — loglik_binomial
text: Computes log-likelihood binomial observations. L(p|x,n) = Σxᵢ*log(p) + (nᵢ-xᵢ)*log(1-p) + log(C(nᵢ,xᵢ))

title: Logistic regression log-likelihood (binary) — loglik_logistic

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
text: Finds optimum using Newton-Raphson method exact Hessian. Uses second-order information faster convergence near optimum.

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
code: newton_raphson(   objective_fn,   params,   max_iter = 100,   tol = 1e-08,   maximize = TRUE,   step_scale = 1,   verbose = 0 )

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
text: objective_fn Function taking list value parameters, returns scalar params List value objects (initial parameter values) max_iter Maximum iterations, default 100 tol Convergence tolerance step size, default 1e-8 maximize TRUE (default), maximize; FALSE, minimize step_scale Scale factor Newton step (< 1 damping), default 1 verbose Print progress every N iterations (0 silent)

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
text: list containing: params List value objects optimum value Objective function value optimum gradient Gradient optimum hessian Hessian optimum iterations Number iterations performed converged TRUE step size < tol

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
text: Newton-Raphson update: θ_n+1 = θ_n - H⁻¹ g maximization, uses: θ_n+1 = θ_n - H⁻¹ g (H negative definite) minimization, uses: θ_n+1 = θ_n - H⁻¹ g (H positive definite) Hessian computed via forward--reverse AD iteration. exact can slow many parameters.

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Find MLE for normal distribution x <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2) loglik <- function(p) loglik_normal(p[[1]], p[[2]], x) result <- newton_raphson(loglik, list(val(0), val(1))) sapply(result$params, data)  # Should be close to c(mean(x), sd(x)) } # }
